question: Give the evidence for the delocalised model of benzene

keypoints.title: Bond lengths
answer: X-ray data shows that the bond lengths for all C-C bonds are the same.
This suggests there cannot be double and single bonds between carbon atoms and delocalisation is more likely.

keypoints.title: Enthalpy change of hydrogenation
answer: If benzene has 3 double bonds then the enthalpy change of hydrogenation should be 3 times as large as it would be for cyclohexene.
When tested experimentally the energy change is significantly less than expected. This suggests the structure is more stable.

keypoints.title: Low reactivity
answer: You would expect a structure with carbon-carbon double bonds to react with bromine under standard conditions.
